newsitem.title: UK: FORECAST - UK house prices to grow, but no boom.
newsitem.headline: FORECAST - UK house prices to grow, but no boom.

text.p: UK house prices will rise by an average of around 4-1/2 percent in 1996 and 6-1/2 percent in 1997, fuelled by increased consumer confidence and improved affordability, economists and mortgage lenders said in a Reuters survey.

But the 16 respondents stressed that, while prices would grow by more than the 2-3 percent predicted in a previous survey in March, the increase would be gradual and could taper off towards the end of 1997 as an expected post-election monetary tightening took its toll.
Yet it is still good news for the ruling Conservative party, searching for signs of a "feel-good" factor to boost re-election prospects. A UK general election must be held by May 1997.
Lehman Brothers and Williams de Broe, with their respective 1997 forecasts of 10.6 and 15.5 percent, are anticipating stronger growth.

"Builders are not increasing the number of starts significantly, so all the extra demand translates into prices rather than a mixture of prices and volumes," explained Michael Dicks, UK economist at Lehman Brothers.

Economists reckon consumers are once again viewing houses as an investment vehicle which could produce positive returns and this is encouraging demand, despite many home-owners still languishing under a cloud of negative equity.
"People's memories are short. When they smell the possibility of making money they forget about the events of the past," said Rob Thomas, housing analyst at UBS.
At the moment, houses look cheap in relation to income, economists said, with strengthening earnings nudged higher by tax cuts.
"We're seeing a pickup in demand for housing driven by the fact that real take-home pay has accelerated quite sharply," said Lehman's Dicks.
This, combined with a low interest rate environment, has tempted would-be sellers back to the market.
"The housing market has been moribund for about five years, so there's a bit of catch-up going on," said Ian Amstad, senior European economist at BT Gilts.
Recent price data released by the Halifax and Nationwide building societies pointed to a steady housing market recovery rather than a full-scale boom.
As the market picks up, the number of transactions will start to catch up with the recent price increases, economists said.
"Sellers will start coming back into the market and this will help to slow down the rate of increase of prices," said Ian Shepherdson, chief UK economist at HSBC James Capel.

"I don't think it will get to the point where it starts pushing prices down again, but I think it will moderate the rate of increase and we'll see a continued steady increase rather than any sort of boom," he added.

Other factors which would put a lid on any house price surge include the predicted rising cost of financing a mortgage and a reluctance among consumers to increase their level of debt, as well as a possible fiscal tightening after the general election.
"The economy will be growing next year and ... interest rates will no longer be falling so in effect the cost of finance is going to rise," said Trevor Williams, economic advisor at Lloyds Bank.

"Fiscal policy stance in a run-up to an election is usually loose. Post election, this will tighten and the income effect on that will mean house price growth will be not much above five percent," he added.
The Halifax house price index showed a seasonally adjusted monthly house price inflation rate of 0.5 percent in August, making an annual rate of 5.7 percent.
The Nationwide's index pointed to a seasonally adjusted increase of 1.7 percent in August, corresponding to an unadjusted annual rise of 5.4 percent.
Detailed results of the poll on annual average house price growth follow. Ten building societies were contacted in total, but seven declined to participate in the survey.
